articles.title: Prediations
articles.summary: This document, from the San Jose Astronomical Association in 1978, outlines a schedule of upcoming events from late July through September. It features a variety of activities including joint conferences with other astronomical organizations, numerous outdoor and indoor star parties, and regular board and general meetings. Key events include speakers on topics like Stonehenge and Space Settlements, and a planned lunar graze occultation expedition.

articles.title: The Finest Deep Sky Objects on the Skalnate Pleso Atlas of the Heavens Chart V
articles.summary: This document serves as an observational guide to a selection of the finest deep sky objects located on Skalnate Pleso Atlas of the Heavens Chart V. It provides detailed descriptions for various nebulae and star clusters, including their coordinates, type, magnitude, size, and extensive notes on their visual appearance and recommended observing techniques. Highlighted objects include the Ring Nebula (M.57), Dumbbell Nebula (M.27), and the Veil Nebula, offering advice for optimal viewing.

articles.title: Blurbs
articles.summary: This bulletin section, "Blurbs," informs members about overdue dues and the impending loss of bulletin access for non-renewals, while also introducing a new 'Question of the Month' feature. It announces an invitation to a San Mateo club meeting, provides a health update on member John Rhodes, and makes a strong call for article submissions and astronomical clippings for the bulletin and a new club scrapbook.

articles.title: EDITORIAL
articles.summary: This editorial expresses disappointment with a formal banquet, contrasting its staid atmosphere with a fun, informal board meeting. The author suggests a more casual event with barbecued hot dogs and hamburgers for next year, believing it would better suit the attendees.

articles.title: How did you first learn about the SJAA? Chances are excellent it was a friend who brought you to your first meeting or star party. We have acquired new members through school instructors and referrals from instrument dealers, but usually we meet our new members through their friends. And probably for a very good reason; many astronomy-oriented people tend to be a bit shy (though I can think of a few counter-examples) and personal contact is most convincing.
articles.summary: The article explores how new members typically join the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), finding that personal referrals from friends are the most effective method, often due to the shy nature of astronomy enthusiasts. It encourages current members to invite friends who might be interested but are unaware of the SJAA, emphasizing the importance of sharing enthusiasm and personal contact to grow the organization.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS Don Machholz (356-7727)
articles.summary: Don Machholz provides updates on current comets, noting Periodic Comet Ashbrook-Jackson (1977c) rising in the east at magnitude 12+ and Comet Meier (1976P) setting in the west, soon to be visible from the Southern Hemisphere. He also mentions the unobservable Comet Shajn-Schaldach (1978i) and highlights veteran comet hunter Jack Bennett, who continues his search in the Southern Hemisphere despite facing light pollution.

articles.title: July Star Parties - Bob Fingerhut
articles.summary: Bob Fingerhut recounts two July star parties at Chews Ridge and a private observing session at Fremont Peak, detailing the varying sky conditions and participants. Despite initial high fog, attendees enjoyed dark skies for observing and photographing on several nights, notably witnessing a Vandenberg rocket launch.

articles.title: First Impressions of the July 22 Indoor Star Party - Wayne Johnson (Tucson Astronomical and Aeronautical Association)
articles.summary: Wayne Johnson, visiting from Tucson, initially found the concept of an "Indoor Star Party" and the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) members quite quirky. Despite the initial eccentricities, he was highly impressed by the group's diversity, efficiency, and the valuable discussions on topics like photographic techniques and grazing occultations. Johnson regretted not finding the SJAA sooner, as he would only be in San Jose for the summer, and suggested improved advertising for the association.

articles.title: Secretary's Library - Cathy Pinheiro
articles.summary: Cathy Pinheiro, the club's Secretary, continues to list available books, magazines, and pamphlets from the club's library for members to borrow, including titles on deep-sky objects, the moon, and the history of astronomy. The article also announces an upcoming spectacular lunar graze of a 6.2 magnitude double star on September 23/24 and plans for an expedition and star party west of Fresno or north of King City.

articles.title: Occultation of star by Hurculana
articles.summary: The article reports on two distinct astronomical events: an occultation by asteroid 532 Herculina, which resulted in the discovery of a possible satellite by southern observers, though the author and Don Machholz only observed a miss. It also details a recent star party at Sanborn Canyon attended by many amateur astronomers, highlighting various activities, social interactions, and minor issues like a new observer struggling with constellations.

articles.title: Penny Pinochle!
articles.summary: A group of amateur astronomers gathered on Clay Station Road for a "graze" expedition on July 2nd, hoping to observe a lunar occultation. Despite thorough preparation, a large turnout, and initially clear skies, unexpected low, dense clouds arrived just before the central occultation, rendering the scientific aspect of the expedition a failure. Nevertheless, participants considered the event a success for its social camaraderie, learning experience, and fun.

articles.title: Board Meeting at Debbie Moore's, July 14.
articles.summary: A board meeting held at Debbie Moore's on July 14 began with recreational activities including swimming, a barbecue, and billiards, involving several members like Gerry Rattley, Jim Van Nuland, and Bob Fingerhut. Hours later, the board officially convened to discuss graze results, an upcoming banquet, and review the calendar. The author considered it the most enjoyable board meeting they had attended.

articles.title: AANC Messier Club
articles.summary: The AANC Messier Club program encourages amateur astronomers to observe all 107 Messier objects, offering a plaque for completion and a parchment for spotting 75 objects. Participants must register with the AANC, use their own instrument, and record their observations within a two-year period to be eligible for recognition.
